questions.question: What is a minimum supplemental oxygen requirement to be supplied in a pressurized aeroplane during an emergency descent?
options: A supply of oxygen sufficient for all crew and passengers to enable a shallow rate of descent to 10000 ft or 2 hours whichever is the longer
A supply of oxygen for the crew only for the entire time the aeroplane cabin pressure is above 8000 ft
A supply for all crew and passengers sufficient for a constant rate of descent from the aeroplane's maximum certificated operating altitude to 15000 ft in 10 minutes
A supply for 10% of passengers whilst the cabin pressure is over 13000 ft
questions.solution: A supply for all crew and passengers sufficient for a constant rate of descent from the aeroplane's maximum certificated operating altitude to 15000 ft in 10 minutes

questions.question: In a rapid or explosive decompression:
options: the cabin pressure control system immediately reduces the cabin pressure to ambient pressure to prevent the fuselage integrity being destroyed
the cabin altitude quickly or instantaneously reduces to ambient (outside) pressure
the cause of the decompression is usually catastrophic failure of the pressure hull
cabin pressurization system failure will be the first indication that something is wrong
questions.solution: the cabin altitude quickly or instantaneously reduces to ambient (outside) pressure

questions.question: The difference between slow and rapid decompression is:
options: a rapid decompression will be immediately noticeable, a slow decompression will require instrumentation to detect the failure
a rapid decompression is caused by a pressure hull rupture whereas a slow decompression is caused by system failure
the rate at which the cabin altitude climbs with respect to the desired climb setting or the automatic control setting
the speed with which the cabin altitude rises with respect to the ambient (outside) pressure
questions.solution: the speed with which the cabin altitude rises with respect to the ambient (outside) pressure

questions.question: During a slow decompression, passengers will notice:
options: the cabin temperature will fall as the pressure reduces
body cavities (sinuses, ears etc.) will become pressurized and may require assistance in venting
as soon as the pressure falls, the oxygen drop-out system will operate
no contra effects, as slow depressurization has no effect on the human body
questions.solution: body cavities (sinuses, ears etc.) will become pressurized and may require assistance in venting

questions.question: During a rapid or explosive decompression, passengers may notice:
options: gross discomfort, breathlessness, possible damage to sinus cavities
tunnel vision and sensorial depletion
marked reduction in night vision
pain in muscles and joints caused by the bends
questions.solution: gross discomfort, breathlessness, possible damage to sinus cavities

questions.question: In the event of a cabin depressurization, the actions of the pilot will be to:
options: immediately commence a diversion to a suitable alternate
increase engine power to provide additional airflow to the pressurization systems
maintain the aeroplane attitude to prevent further damage to the airframe by over loading of the structure
commence a descent to an altitude where the supplemental oxygen supply is sufficient for all crew and passengers
questions.solution: commence a descent to an altitude where the supplemental oxygen supply is sufficient for all crew and passengers
